question.text: Which of the following most closely depicts the correct variation of the gravitation potential, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></math> with distance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi></math> due to a large planet of radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi></math> and uniform mass density? (figures are not drawn to scale)

solution.text: At inside points <math><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo><</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfenced></math>. So at the centre,   <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>⇒</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mfrac><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mfrac><mi> </mi></math>. At outside points <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>></mo><mi>R</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>G</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mi>r</mi></mfrac></math>. At surface, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>G</mi><mi>M</mi></mrow><mi>R</mi></mfrac></math>. So the gravitational potential is non-uniform and negative.
